title: Trump calls on Fed to slash interest rates as Powell says he doesn’t expect recession
text:
Associated Press President Donald Trump on Friday asked ‘where did I find’ the Fed chairman he nominated.

President Donald Trump on Friday made his latest demand for the Federal Reserve to more aggressively cut interest rates, as Fed chief Jerome Powell said he didn’t see a recession on the horizon.

‘WHERE DID I FIND THIS GUY JEROME?’

Trump didn’t have public events scheduled but was busy on Twitter, where he said he agreed with CNBC host Jim Cramer that the Fed should lower rates.

“They were WAY too early to raise, and Way too late to cut -- and big dose quantitative tightening didn’t exactly help either. Where did I find this guy Jerome? Oh well, you can’t win them all!” Trump said ahead of Powell’s question-and-answer session in Zurich. The president nominated Powell to run the Fed in November 2017.

Powell, speaking after the government reported August jobs data, said the monthly figures fit into an overall picture of a healthy jobs market and economy. He said the Fed is “not forecasting or expecting a recession.”

Now read: Powell says August job report is a sign of continued strength in labor market, doesn’t see a recession.

The economy added just 130,000 new jobs in August, offering more evidence hiring has slowed and making it all but certain to keep the Fed on track to cut interest rates later this month.

See: U.S. creates just 130,000 new jobs in August, keeping Fed on track to cut rates.

U.S. stocks ended mostly higher Friday after the jobs data was released and Powell spoke, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.26% rising 69 points and the S&P 500 index SPX, +0.09% climbing nearly three points. The Nasdaq COMP, -0.17% slipped about 14 points. The U.S. dollar DXY, -0.41% was flat against its major competitors.

Trump has frequently called on Powell to cut rates. The Fed chairman has said that the central bank’s decisions are not political.
